text.p: The following are the main stories from Monday morning's German newspapers:
FRANKFURTER ALLGEMEINE ZEITUNG
- Continuing turbulence in the ruling coalition. Government parties continue to argue over planned tax reform. Delegates at Christian Democrats party congress discuss income tax reform.
- Daimler-Benz supervisory board call for new plan to restructure the firm. Head of Mercedes Helmut Werner goes on defensive
- Berlin wants to become location for IAA, Germany's international automobile exhibition
- Chemical employers' association wants to keep to industry-wide wage agreements
- Metal and engineering sector employers' association Gesamtmetall demands reduction in additional wage costs
HANDELSBLATT

- Chemical workers call for reform of industry-wide wage agreements. Werner Stumpfe president of employers' association Gesamtmetall says metalworkers are asking too much. Metal employers want to raise 1997 wages and salaries but cut additional wage costs
- Shortly before Christian Democrats' (CDU) party congress opened in Hanover, economic politicians called for a change in planned sweeping tax reforms
- Chancellor Helmut Kohl's CDU and junior coalition partner Free Democrats argue about when to start reducing solidarity tax
- Countdown to Deutsche Telekom's flotation in the stock market.
SUEDDEUTSCHE ZEITUNG
- Bonn's ruling coalition divided over when to start reducing solidarity tax
- Low participation in local election for mayor in Stuttgart
- Chancellor Helmut Kohl's CDU party prepares for party congress in Hanover
- Life assurance firms say they are prepared to do away with several privileges
- Post Minister Wlfgang Boetsch says more jobs to be cut in the German post company
- Prosecutors order Siemens offices to be searched again in connection with an investigation into backdated early retirement contracts
- Economics Minister Guenter Rexrodt says economy grew in 1996 by one percent
- A survey showed that customers in Germany have never been less satisfied
DIE WELT
- Solidarity tax will not be reduced until 1998. Free Democrats urge reducing petroleum tax from 7.5 percent to 5.5 percent.
- Free Democrats demand radical changes in tenancy law
- Turks have smuggled 90,000 Kurds into Germany
- Parliamentary committee on finance has completed discussion of inheritance tax. This should come into force after a decision by the constitutional court later this year.
